sn12.35:1.3: Choices are a condition for consciousness. …
sn12.35:1.4: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.”
sn12.35:1.5: When this was said, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,
sn12.35:1.6: “What are old age and death, sir, and who do they belong to?”
sn12.35:1.7: “That’s not a fitting question,” said the Buddha. “You might say, ‘What are old age and death, and who do they belong to?’ Or you might say, ‘Old age and death are one thing, who they belong to is another.’ But both of these mean the same thing, only the phrasing differs.
sn12.35:1.8: Mendicant, if you have the view that the soul and the body are the same thing, there is no living of the spiritual life.
sn12.35:1.9: If you have the view that the soul and the body are different things, there is no living of the spiritual life.
sn12.35:1.10: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One teaches by the middle way:
sn12.35:1.11: ‘Rebirth is a condition for old age and death.’”
sn12.35:2.1: “What is rebirth, sir, and who does it belong to?”
sn12.35:2.2: “That’s not a fitting question,” said the Buddha. “You might say, ‘What is rebirth, and who does it belong to?’ Or you might say, ‘Rebirth is one thing, who it belongs to is another.’ But both of these mean the same thing, only the phrasing differs.
sn12.35:2.3: Mendicant, if you have the view that the soul and the body are the same thing, there is no living of the spiritual life.
sn12.35:2.4: If you have the view that the soul and the body are different things, there is no living of the spiritual life.
sn12.35:2.5: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One teaches by the middle way:
sn12.35:2.6: ‘Continued existence is a condition for rebirth.’”
sn12.35:3.1: “What is continued existence, sir, and who is it for?”
sn12.35:3.2: “That’s not a fitting question,” said the Buddha. “You might say, ‘What is continued existence, and who does it belong to?’ Or you might say, ‘Continued existence is one thing, who it belongs to is another.’ But both of these mean the same thing, only the phrasing differs.
sn12.35:3.3: Mendicant, if you have the view that the soul and the body are identical, there is no living of the spiritual life.
sn12.35:3.4: If you have the view that the soul and the body are different things, there is no living of the spiritual life.
sn12.35:3.5: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One teaches by the middle way:
sn12.35:3.6: ‘Grasping is a condition for continued existence.’ …
sn12.35:3.10: ‘The six sense fields are conditions for contact.’ …
sn12.35:3.11: ‘Name and form are conditions for the six sense fields.’ …
sn12.35:3.12: ‘Consciousness is a condition for name and form.’ …
sn12.35:4.1: “What are choices, sir, and who do they belong to?”
sn12.35:4.2: “That’s not a fitting question,” said the Buddha. “You might say, ‘What are choices, and who do they belong to?’ Or you might say, ‘Choices are one thing, who they belong to is another.’ But both of these mean the same thing, only the phrasing differs.
sn12.35:4.3: Mendicant, if you have the view that the soul and the body are the same thing, there is no living of the spiritual life.
sn12.35:4.4: If you have the view that the soul and the body are different things, there is no living of the spiritual life.
sn12.35:4.5: Avoiding these two extremes, the Realized One teaches by the middle way:
sn12.35:5.1: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, then any tricks, dodges, and evasions are given up:
sn12.35:5.2: ‘What are old age and death, and who do they belong to?’ or ‘old age and death are one thing, who they belong to is another’, or ‘the soul and the body are the same thing’, or ‘the soul and the body are different things.’
sn12.35:5.3: These are all cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.
sn12.35:6.1: When ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, then any tricks, dodges, and evasions are given up:
sn12.35:6.2: ‘What is rebirth, and who does it belong to?’ or ‘rebirth is one thing, who it belongs to is another’, or ‘the soul and the body are the same thing’, or ‘the soul and the body are different things.’
sn12.35:6.3: These are all cut off at the root, made like a palm stump, obliterated, and unable to arise in the future.
